solution_line_template: Sam worked for {sam_hours_worked} hours yesterday, so he was able to complete {sam_hours_worked} hours * {minutes_per_hour} minutes per hour / {sam_time_per_widget} minutes per widget = <<{sam_hours_worked}*{minutes_per_hour}/{sam_time_per_widget}={sam_widgets_completed}>>{sam_widgets_completed} widgets.

Jack worked for {jack_hours_worked} hours, so he was able to complete {jack_hours_worked} hours * {minutes_per_hour} minutes per hour / {jack_time_per_widget} minutes per widget = <<{jack_hours_worked}*{minutes_per_hour}/{jack_time_per_widget}={jack_widgets_completed}>>{jack_widgets_completed} widgets.

Sam, Jack, and Tony were able to complete {total_widgets_completed} widgets together. So of those, Tony personally completed {total_widgets_completed} widgets - {sam_widgets_completed} widgets - {jack_widgets_completed} widgets = <<{total_widgets_completed}-{sam_widgets_completed}-{jack_widgets_completed}={tony_widgets_completed}>>{tony_widgets_completed} widgets.

It took Tony {tony_hours_worked} hours to complete those {tony_widgets_completed} widgets, so he takes {tony_hours_worked} hours * {minutes_per_hour} minutes per hour / {tony_widgets_completed} widgets = <<{tony_hours_worked}*{minutes_per_hour}/{tony_widgets_completed}={tony_time_per_widget}>>{tony_time_per_widget} minutes per widget.
